channel.title: My thirst for knowledge
channel.description:
The title says it all, I'm wondering how each of you learned to program and hopefully debate on the best road to travel for me, I'm truly hoping that by posting this and you all replying that I will find the best way for me to learn.
So, How did each of you learn, and what would you consider the best way (outside of a classroom)

item.title: My thirst for knowledge
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

As much as it would be fun to see how this ends, there’s a limit to ignorance, even on these boards.

If you aren’t willing to take the advice of the members of this forum, however crudely it is presented, then I don’t see why you seek intellectual refuge here. It’s just a forum about Java. You could have asked your question, then been on your way, rather than sitting and poking fights at every person that posts on this topic.

But yeah, nothing good can come from this topic anymore.

Read full topic

item.title: My thirst for knowledge
item.dc:creator: @Get_Forgotten Get_Forgotten
item.description:
@Get_Forgotten wrote:

[quote=“Cain_”][quote author=Get_Forgotten link=topic=465350.msg3406861#msg3406861 date=1290380331]
To be completely honest i think it quite hilarious that all of you come to defend one fucking moron, There by claiming all of yourselves complete idiots, I’m starting to think apart from a few respectful people all of you have alot of growing to do mentally, Not just me, But all of you, I’ll be the first to admit i have moments of immaturity but I’m not going to rage flame every thread that doesn’t suit my standards, And to anyone who does that (Unhandled) it shows very obviously that you have no life, or your badgered in real life cause your an idiot, and you want to piss people off over the internet to make your self feel somewhat adequate in your pitiful inadequate lives.

ITT: nobody loves you go cry.
[/quote]

tl;dr: Forgotten is a moron who lacks the ability to come up with decent insults, and doesn’t know how to differentiate between “your” and “you’re”.[/quote]

I know the difference I just don’t see the importance of using You’re I’m not an english major and don’t plan to be a english teacher so its not important, and I don’t need to insult those who insult themselves, So gf faggot.

Read full topic

item.title: My thirst for knowledge
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

[quote=“Get_Forgotten, post:25, topic:369217”][quote author=Unhandled link=topic=465350.msg3404210#msg3404210 date=1290204115]

Pass I’ll neither just deal with it nor go away.

Great, stick around and keep raging like the prepubescent bitch you are.

I for one find it fucking hilarious!
[/quote]

To be completely honest I’m probably older than you and obviously you’ve got some kind of inferiority complex that makes you be a fucking moron and makes you want to act like a dick to people over the internet grow a pair fag boy, and Greeny my previous posts have nothing to do with what I’m doing now, Yes I’ve tried to learn java before but life overall trumped my journey I know it may be hard to believe someone on this forum has a fucking life, But unlike Unhandled here I have a set of testicles and I’m not trying to be a bad-ass online to make myself feel better.

as it says in my sig Stupidity is a virus and obviously you’ve been affected by it horribly unhandled[/quote]
Fuck off. Pulling rank doesn’t work unless you have rank to pull. That doesn’t matter though, because only idiots have to resort to pulling rank in the first place anyway. By rank I mean age, obviously.

Having read some of your previous posts, I know that you’re apparently 18 (having made a post in 2008 stating that you were 16). Your attempt at witty rhetoric was less impressive than that of a smart arsed primary school student.
With that in mind, I can safely say that you aren’t actually 18. If you are 18 physically then you’ve got a long way to go mentally.
Don’t have a whinge because a couple of forthcoming people were kind enough to tell you what’s what when it comes to succeeding or failing at something.

There are two kinds of people at the end of the day – haves, and have-nots.

The haves don’t even need to make topics like this; they’re driven enough to read the resource list topic, find an ebook, and then run with it. Two months later they’re programming like a natural. They may or may not then start asking structured questions with regards to the finer nuances of what they’ve applied themselves to; everyone here welcomes that.

The have-nots are like you; undriven, unmotivated, incapable of directing their own study and, ultimately, destined to fail – if they even start, that is.

Someone has already given you the best answer when it comes to programming. ‘Read a book’. The books have example code that you can work through. Some books will omit boilerplate code for the sake of brevity, but many have fully functional code examples which you can play with to discover what works and what doesn’t.
As for not being able to learn from a book, my only response to that is ‘toughen up’. If you want something, and I mean really want something, then you make it work.

tl;dr: This isn’t the Matrix, where JavaKung Fu is learnt in a couple of seconds.

Read full topic

item.title: My thirst for knowledge
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

[quote=“Get_Forgotten, post:25, topic:369217”][quote author=Unhandled link=topic=465350.msg3404210#msg3404210 date=1290204115]

Pass I’ll neither just deal with it nor go away.

Great, stick around and keep raging like the prepubescent bitch you are.

I for one find it fucking hilarious!
[/quote]

To be completely honest I’m probably older than you and obviously you’ve got some kind of inferiority complex that makes you be a fucking moron and makes you want to act like a dick to people over the internet grow a pair fag boy, and Greeny my previous posts have nothing to do with what I’m doing now, Yes I’ve tried to learn java before but life overall trumped my journey I know it may be hard to believe someone on this forum has a fucking life, But unlike Unhandled here I have a set of testicles and I’m not trying to be a bad-ass online to make myself feel better.

as it says in my sig Stupidity is a virus and obviously you’ve been affected by it horribly unhandled[/quote]

Looks like you infected yourself, I mentioned this earlier in the thread but you just capitalised “stupidity”, congratulations on defining yourself with it.

I doubt you’re older than me, if you are >20 then I’d expect you to have the maturity to do as people have said and pick up a book and learn. Of course age is irrelevant, you’re asking for help with programming and programming is more or less governed by experience so since you’re the one asking for help (therefore zero experience) maybe it’d make sense to shut the fuck up and just listen to some advice?

You can’t just learn Java over night, you’re blatantly a lazy, sorry, and mislead individual if after two years of trying you’re still trying to find a method of learning something which has been published in thousands of books. It requires picking one up and reading, then doing. How hard to understand is that? or maybe you’d just like to continue ignoring our advice and just throw a few more grammatically incorrect flames our way.

Read full topic

item.title: My thirst for knowledge
item.dc:creator: @Rixxx Rix_
item.description:
@Rixxx wrote:

Start out by doing a few really, really simple Java practices on CodingBat [link] without looking at the answers. They’re basic and I think you are able to do them without looking at the answers. You can also have a look at a few tutorials on Oracle. Usually there are a few questions at the end, so answer them. Now that you’ve gotten a grasp of basic Java, try writing any program (here’s a list of programs you might want to look at: http://www.cs.princeton.edu/introcs/code) you feel confident doing so.

If you fail, don’t worry, I know you did your best; just try again, good luck! go kill yourself.

Read full topic

item.title: My thirst for knowledge
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

I found it best to find something easy to do but challenging enough to have to learn something new about the language(an irc bot for example), google code snippets, hack it together then read the official tutorials to see how it all works.

I also think it would help to disregard my advise, I never really knew enough about java to make things on my own, and still haven’t learned anything.

Read full topic

item.title: My thirst for knowledge
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

[quote=“Get_Forgotten, post:15, topic:369217”]Some of these posts are actually quite helpful, Some on the other hand, Are not…

Its been proven that I learn best not by “reading a fucking book”, Rather by doing hands on work where I can give it my best and then fix anything I may have made a mistake on.

I knew this but didn’t really know where to begin.

So I’d like to thank both Ollie and Nueb for giving me ideas on where to look for these ‘Hands on’ Projects.

And as for Unhandled and M.dog. I’ve tried both but was Unsuccessful because I cannot learn by simply reading things. I have to be involved in some way.[/quote]

Here’s a tip straight away, you can’t capitalise random words when you’re programming or it just wont work. If you do it in your normal everyday typing then you’re not paying enough attention to detail. Programming like anything is a skill made up of skills, you need a keen eye and precise logical thinking in order to avoid making lots of silly mistakes that will just cost you vast quantities of time to fix.

If you’re motivated to learn you should start proof reading posts, modifying grammar and spelling mistakes. Java is far more complicated than writing a forum post, you need to get in good habits now. Also RAFB.

Read full topic

And as for Unhandled and M.dog. I’ve tried both but was Unsuccessful because I cannot learn by simply reading things. I have to be involved in some way.[/quote]

Then be involved? Just sit down, think of a program you want, make it while using books as references.

item.title: My thirst for knowledge
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

First set a goal for what you want to accomplish.
Read a book about Java , DON’T rely on tutorials, they are usable if you want to do a single thing, but you learn little of it.
Read more about general programming, since just knowing the language would not get you to the goal.

On the way, find a good solution about how to use what you have learned to solve problems. As Ollie wrote, using it to do homework in Math and Physics can be a nice way.

Read full topic

item.title: My thirst for knowledge

http://projecteuler.net, create programs to solve these things

item.title: My thirst for knowledge
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

I think its pretty certain which language he wants to learn m.dog311, as he is posting in the ‘Java Programming’ section after all. Im surprised you didn’t bring up your creation of your own java compiler, or was it not you?

I find the best way to learn is by doing, get hands on and solve some problems which you need to solve for your own needs. I used to create algorithms to solve my math homework so it would take a vast amount of time less and leave me to play my games more ;p cheating but hey, its the result not how you got there right?

Read full topic
